005package edu.wpi.first.math.estimator;
006
007import edu.wpi.first.math.MathSharedStore;
008import edu.wpi.first.math.Matrix;
009import edu.wpi.first.math.Nat;
010import edu.wpi.first.math.VecBuilder;
011import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Pose2d;
012import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
013import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Twist2d;
014import edu.wpi.first.math.interpolation.Interpolatable;
015import edu.wpi.first.math.interpolation.TimeInterpolatableBuffer;
016import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.Kinematics;
017import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.Odometry;
018import edu.wpi.first.math.numbers.N1;
019import edu.wpi.first.math.numbers.N3;
020import java.util.Map;
021import java.util.NoSuchElementException;
022import java.util.Objects;
023import java.util.Optional;
024
025/**
026 * This class wraps {@link Odometry} to fuse latency-compensated vision measurements with encoder
027 * measurements. Robot code should not use this directly- Instead, use the particular type for your
028 * drivetrain (e.g., {@link DifferentialDrivePoseEstimator}). It is intended to be a drop-in
029 * replacement for {@link Odometry}; in fact, if you never call {@link
030 * PoseEstimator#addVisionMeasurement} and only call {@link PoseEstimator#update} then this will
031 * behave exactly the same as Odometry.
032 *
033 * <p>{@link PoseEstimator#update} should be called every robot loop.
034 *
035 * <p>{@link PoseEstimator#addVisionMeasurement} can be called as infrequently as you want; if you
036 * never call it then this class will behave exactly like regular encoder odometry.
037 *
038 * @param <T> Wheel positions type.
039 */
040public class PoseEstimator<T> {
041  private final Kinematics<?, T> m_kinematics;
042  private final Odometry<T> m_odometry;
043  private final Matrix<N3, N1> m_q = new Matrix<>(Nat.N3(), Nat.N1());
044  private final Matrix<N3, N3> m_visionK = new Matrix<>(Nat.N3(), Nat.N3());
045
046  private static final double kBufferDuration = 1.5;
047  private final TimeInterpolatableBuffer<InterpolationRecord> m_poseBuffer =
048      TimeInterpolatableBuffer.createBuffer(kBufferDuration);
049
050  /**
051   * Constructs a PoseEstimator.
052   *
053   * @param kinematics A correctly-configured kinematics object for your drivetrain.
054   * @param odometry A correctly-configured odometry object for your drivetrain.
055   * @param stateStdDevs Standard deviations of the pose estimate (x position in meters, y position
056   *     in meters, and heading in radians). Increase these numbers to trust your state estimate
057   *     less.
058   * @param visionMeasurementStdDevs Standard deviations of the vision pose measurement (x position
059   *     in meters, y position in meters, and heading in radians). Increase these numbers to trust
060   *     the vision pose measurement less.
061   */
062  public PoseEstimator(
063      Kinematics<?, T> kinematics,
064      Odometry<T> odometry,
065      Matrix<N3, N1> stateStdDevs,
066      Matrix<N3, N1> visionMeasurementStdDevs) {
067    m_kinematics = kinematics;
068    m_odometry = odometry;
069
070    for (int i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
071      m_q.set(i, 0, stateStdDevs.get(i, 0) * stateStdDevs.get(i, 0));
072    }
073    setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(visionMeasurementStdDevs);
074  }
075
076  /**
077   * Sets the pose estimator's trust of global measurements. This might be used to change trust in
078   * vision measurements after the autonomous period, or to change trust as distance to a vision
079   * target increases.
080   *
081   * @param visionMeasurementStdDevs Standard deviations of the vision measurements. Increase these
082   *     numbers to trust global measurements from vision less. This matrix is in the form [x, y,
083   *     theta]áµ€, with units in meters and radians.
084   */
085  public final void setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(Matrix<N3, N1> visionMeasurementStdDevs) {
086    var r = new double[3];
087    for (int i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
088      r[i] = visionMeasurementStdDevs.get(i, 0) * visionMeasurementStdDevs.get(i, 0);
089    }
090
091    // Solve for closed form Kalman gain for continuous Kalman filter with A = 0
092    // and C = I. See wpimath/algorithms.md.
093    for (int row = 0; row < 3; ++row) {
094      if (m_q.get(row, 0) == 0.0) {
095        m_visionK.set(row, row, 0.0);
096      } else {
097        m_visionK.set(
098            row, row, m_q.get(row, 0) / (m_q.get(row, 0) + Math.sqrt(m_q.get(row, 0) * r[row])));
099      }
100    }
101  }
102
103  /**
104   * Resets the robot's position on the field.
105   *
106   * <p>The gyroscope angle does not need to be reset here on the user's robot code. The library
107   * automatically takes care of offsetting the gyro angle.
108   *
109   * @param gyroAngle The angle reported by the gyroscope.
110   * @param wheelPositions The current encoder readings.
111   * @param poseMeters The position on the field that your robot is at.
112   */
113  public void resetPosition(Rotation2d gyroAngle, T wheelPositions, Pose2d poseMeters) {
114    // Reset state estimate and error covariance
115    m_odometry.resetPosition(gyroAngle, wheelPositions, poseMeters);
116    m_poseBuffer.clear();
117  }
118
119  /**
120   * Gets the estimated robot pose.
121   *
122   * @return The estimated robot pose in meters.
123   */
124  public Pose2d getEstimatedPosition() {
125    return m_odometry.getPoseMeters();
126  }
127
128  /**
129   * Return the pose at a given timestamp, if the buffer is not empty.
130   *
131   * @param timestampSeconds The pose's timestamp in seconds.
132   * @return The pose at the given timestamp (or Optional.empty() if the buffer is empty).
133   */
134  public Optional<Pose2d> sampleAt(double timestampSeconds) {
135    return m_poseBuffer.getSample(timestampSeconds).map(record -> record.poseMeters);
136  }
137
138  /**
139   * Adds a vision measurement to the Kalman Filter. This will correct the odometry pose estimate
140   * while still accounting for measurement noise.
141   *
142   * <p>This method can be called as infrequently as you want, as long as you are calling {@link
143   * PoseEstimator#update} every loop.
144   *
145   * <p>To promote stability of the pose estimate and make it robust to bad vision data, we
146   * recommend only adding vision measurements that are already within one meter or so of the
147   * current pose estimate.
148   *
149   * @param visionRobotPoseMeters The pose of the robot as measured by the vision camera.
150   * @param timestampSeconds The timestamp of the vision measurement in seconds. Note that if you
151   *     don't use your own time source by calling {@link
152   *     PoseEstimator#updateWithTime(double,Rotation2d,Object)} then you must use a timestamp with
153   *     an epoch since FPGA startup (i.e., the epoch of this timestamp is the same epoch as {@link
154   *     edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer#getFPGATimestamp()}.) This means that you should use {@link
155   *     edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer#getFPGATimestamp()} as your time source or sync the epochs.
156   */
157  public void addVisionMeasurement(Pose2d visionRobotPoseMeters, double timestampSeconds) {
158    // Step 0: If this measurement is old enough to be outside the pose buffer's timespan, skip.
159    try {
160      if (m_poseBuffer.getInternalBuffer().lastKey() - kBufferDuration > timestampSeconds) {
161        return;
162      }
163    } catch (NoSuchElementException ex) {
164      return;
165    }
166
167    // Step 1: Get the pose odometry measured at the moment the vision measurement was made.
168    var sample = m_poseBuffer.getSample(timestampSeconds);
169
170    if (sample.isEmpty()) {
171      return;
172    }
173
174    // Step 2: Measure the twist between the odometry pose and the vision pose.
175    var twist = sample.get().poseMeters.log(visionRobotPoseMeters);
176
177    // Step 3: We should not trust the twist entirely, so instead we scale this twist by a Kalman
178    // gain matrix representing how much we trust vision measurements compared to our current pose.
179    var k_times_twist = m_visionK.times(VecBuilder.fill(twist.dx, twist.dy, twist.dtheta));
180
181    // Step 4: Convert back to Twist2d.
182    var scaledTwist =
183        new Twist2d(k_times_twist.get(0, 0), k_times_twist.get(1, 0), k_times_twist.get(2, 0));
184
185    // Step 5: Reset Odometry to state at sample with vision adjustment.
186    m_odometry.resetPosition(
187        sample.get().gyroAngle,
188        sample.get().wheelPositions,
189        sample.get().poseMeters.exp(scaledTwist));
190
191    // Step 6: Record the current pose to allow multiple measurements from the same timestamp
192    m_poseBuffer.addSample(
193        timestampSeconds,
194        new InterpolationRecord(
195            getEstimatedPosition(), sample.get().gyroAngle, sample.get().wheelPositions));
196
197    // Step 7: Replay odometry inputs between sample time and latest recorded sample to update the
198    // pose buffer and correct odometry.
199    for (Map.Entry<Double, InterpolationRecord> entry :
200        m_poseBuffer.getInternalBuffer().tailMap(timestampSeconds).entrySet()) {
201      updateWithTime(entry.getKey(), entry.getValue().gyroAngle, entry.getValue().wheelPositions);
202    }
203  }
204
205  /**
206   * Adds a vision measurement to the Kalman Filter. This will correct the odometry pose estimate
207   * while still accounting for measurement noise.
208   *
209   * <p>This method can be called as infrequently as you want, as long as you are calling {@link
210   * PoseEstimator#update} every loop.
211   *
212   * <p>To promote stability of the pose estimate and make it robust to bad vision data, we
213   * recommend only adding vision measurements that are already within one meter or so of the
214   * current pose estimate.
215   *
216   * <p>Note that the vision measurement standard deviations passed into this method will continue
217   * to apply to future measurements until a subsequent call to {@link
218   * PoseEstimator#setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(Matrix)} or this method.
219   *
220   * @param visionRobotPoseMeters The pose of the robot as measured by the vision camera.
221   * @param timestampSeconds The timestamp of the vision measurement in seconds. Note that if you
222   *     don't use your own time source by calling {@link #updateWithTime}, then you must use a
223   *     timestamp with an epoch since FPGA startup (i.e., the epoch of this timestamp is the same
224   *     epoch as {@link edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer#getFPGATimestamp()}). This means that you
225   *     should use {@link edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer#getFPGATimestamp()} as your time source in
226   *     this case.
227   * @param visionMeasurementStdDevs Standard deviations of the vision pose measurement (x position
228   *     in meters, y position in meters, and heading in radians). Increase these numbers to trust
229   *     the vision pose measurement less.
230   */
231  public void addVisionMeasurement(
232      Pose2d visionRobotPoseMeters,
233      double timestampSeconds,
234      Matrix<N3, N1> visionMeasurementStdDevs) {
235    setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(visionMeasurementStdDevs);
236    addVisionMeasurement(visionRobotPoseMeters, timestampSeconds);
237  }
238
239  /**
240   * Updates the pose estimator with wheel encoder and gyro information. This should be called every
241   * loop.
242   *
243   * @param gyroAngle The current gyro angle.
244   * @param wheelPositions The current encoder readings.
245   * @return The estimated pose of the robot in meters.
246   */
247  public Pose2d update(Rotation2d gyroAngle, T wheelPositions) {
248    return updateWithTime(MathSharedStore.getTimestamp(), gyroAngle, wheelPositions);
249  }
250
251  /**
252   * Updates the pose estimator with wheel encoder and gyro information. This should be called every
253   * loop.
254   *
255   * @param currentTimeSeconds Time at which this method was called, in seconds.
256   * @param gyroAngle The current gyro angle.
257   * @param wheelPositions The current encoder readings.
258   * @return The estimated pose of the robot in meters.
259   */
260  public Pose2d updateWithTime(double currentTimeSeconds, Rotation2d gyroAngle, T wheelPositions) {
261    m_odometry.update(gyroAngle, wheelPositions);
262    m_poseBuffer.addSample(
263        currentTimeSeconds,
264        new InterpolationRecord(
265            getEstimatedPosition(), gyroAngle, m_kinematics.copy(wheelPositions)));
266
267    return getEstimatedPosition();
268  }
269
270  /**
271   * Represents an odometry record. The record contains the inputs provided as well as the pose that
272   * was observed based on these inputs, as well as the previous record and its inputs.
273   */
274  private final class InterpolationRecord implements Interpolatable<InterpolationRecord> {
275    // The pose observed given the current sensor inputs and the previous pose.
276    private final Pose2d poseMeters;
277
278    // The current gyro angle.
279    private final Rotation2d gyroAngle;
280
281    // The current encoder readings.
282    private final T wheelPositions;
283
284    /**
285     * Constructs an Interpolation Record with the specified parameters.
286     *
287     * @param poseMeters The pose observed given the current sensor inputs and the previous pose.
288     * @param gyro The current gyro angle.
289     * @param wheelPositions The current encoder readings.
290     */
291    private InterpolationRecord(Pose2d poseMeters, Rotation2d gyro, T wheelPositions) {
292      this.poseMeters = poseMeters;
293      this.gyroAngle = gyro;
294      this.wheelPositions = wheelPositions;
295    }
296
297    /**
298     * Return the interpolated record. This object is assumed to be the starting position, or lower
299     * bound.
300     *
301     * @param endValue The upper bound, or end.
302     * @param t How far between the lower and upper bound we are. This should be bounded in [0, 1].
303     * @return The interpolated value.
304     */
305    @Override
306    public InterpolationRecord interpolate(InterpolationRecord endValue, double t) {
307      if (t < 0) {
308        return this;
309      } else if (t >= 1) {
310        return endValue;
311      } else {
312        // Find the new wheel distances.
313        var wheelLerp = m_kinematics.interpolate(wheelPositions, endValue.wheelPositions, t);
314
315        // Find the new gyro angle.
316        var gyroLerp = gyroAngle.interpolate(endValue.gyroAngle, t);
317
318        // Create a twist to represent the change based on the interpolated sensor inputs.
319        Twist2d twist = m_kinematics.toTwist2d(wheelPositions, wheelLerp);
320        twist.dtheta = gyroLerp.minus(gyroAngle).getRadians();
321
322        return new InterpolationRecord(poseMeters.exp(twist), gyroLerp, wheelLerp);
323      }
324    }
325
326    @Override
327    public boolean equals(Object obj) {
328      return this == obj
329          || obj instanceof PoseEstimator<?>.InterpolationRecord record
330              && Objects.equals(gyroAngle, record.gyroAngle)
331              && Objects.equals(wheelPositions, record.wheelPositions)
332              && Objects.equals(poseMeters, record.poseMeters);
333    }
334
335    @Override
336    public int hashCode() {
337      return Objects.hash(gyroAngle, wheelPositions, poseMeters);
338    }
339  }
340}
